posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: My team is upgrading to swerve for next year and I was wondering what’s better for swerve a Pigeon or navx. We have navx currently but the pigeon seems better as a member of my team said so. We use python with magic bot if that changes anything. Thanks for reading and helping if you can.
We have preferred the Pigeon 2, iirc it’s because it’s a dedicated gyro rather than something added onto something else like the navX.

posts.name: Ryan Shavell
posts.cooked: We switched from using a NavX to the Pigeon 2 this season, and the performance seemed noticeably better - we didn’t lose heading on harsh collisions or notice any drift during matches, which would occasionally happen in previous years with the NavX. I highly recommend the Pigeon 2

What does the rest of your drive look like? If your components are CTRE / WCP / SDS then I would go with the pigeon 2. There are some real advantages to staying with a single swerve platform in terms of software. The vendors and tools will deal with the eventual required WPILIB upgrade.  If you mix and match your own your own.  It will save you some time.
I’d go pigeon then. The CTRE tools are really nice and easy to use when completely vertically integrated. You can even add a carnivore and have your drive train on its on CAN . .

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
LPryor:

There are some real advantages to staying with a single swerve platform in terms of software.

Sorta, but I think this gets a touch overstated (or over-emphasized with components that don’t truly matter). Gonna go on a bit of a tangent here:

Keep everything CTRE - use Talon FX motors only with CANcoders and a Pigeon 2, and you can use their swerve code generator. My understanding is that if you change even one thing, the benefit of this is gone. You can also use a CANivore to enable CAN FD on these devices and easily get 250 Hz odometry without CAN bus over-utilization, which is a nice plus. But if you don’t spend the money on the CANivore, that benefit won’t be real, and you’ll be extremely hard pressed to get that update rate otherwise when everything is CAN .

CTRE ’s platform doesn’t actually care what physical modules you run; it’s just easy to mount CANcoders to WCP or SDS . They’re by no means part of the “platform” (especially SDS , who has no direct relationship with CTRE ), they’re just designed with that particular encoder in mind. Thrifty Swerve 2.0 also looks like it’ll support these encoders just fine.

On REV’s side, they don’t have a code generator, but a code template. It is specifically for MAXSwerve, and if you use their configuration with no changes, that’s fine. But “their configuration” is rigid; it’s just an example that uses one specific gear ratio, original NEOs with the SPARK MAX, and an IMU that not many teams use. Change any of those things - including upgrading to the NEO Vortex and SPARK Flex - and you can’t just use it as-is. And at that point, if you have any other preferences in hardware, you may as well make any other changes you prefer. If you’re using REV motor controllers with the Canandcoder on a MK4i, that’d still be fine.

On that note, REV’s swerve calibration tool in their hardware client is nice, and it isn’t really specific to MAXSwerve or their own absolute encoder. Any absolute encoder the SPARK MAX (or Flex, I believe) will work fine, and you can use it with any module so long as you know which way “zero” is supposed to be for each corner. Again - if you’re using REV motor controllers with the Canandcoder on a MK4i, that’d work here.

I’ve also seen people suggest Pigeon for CTRE setups, NavX for REV. REV is pretty IMU-agnostic, since as of this moment they haven’t actually made one themselves. It’s no harder to integrate a Pigeon into a REV-based swerve platform than it is a NavX.

LPryor:

You can even add a carnivore and have your drive train on its on CAN . .

This specific benefit is true regardless of the IMU they go with (assuming they stay within the realm of IMUs commonly used in FRC ), as the Pigeon 2 is the only one to use the CAN bus anyway. A NavX won’t interfere with putting the drive train on a separate CAN bus (and you can poll a NavX over SPI pretty fast, so you can still take advantage of those faster update rates that CAN -FD provides).

All that said, for OP’s case, you may as well go with the Pigeon if everything else is CTRE anyway. I’ve heard nothing but good things about their code generator. Though for all configurations, YAGSL does a pretty good job. You’re not truly on your own for figuring the code out if you mix and match stuff.

re: CTRE right but in this case the user said falcons and camcorders…add a pigeon and that’s a complete CTRE stack. And while their platform doesn’t require a specific module their tools do have presets for WCP and SDS drives. Hence my SDs/ctre/ WCP note.

yagsl is wonderful and does help with the mix and matching. But it can be tricky to configure. (Nstrike gives great support on CD , but we never got it to work well and gave up) In terms of saving time CTRE and taking the rev code drop are much more turnkey. In terms of time saved, going with vertical integration is where it’s at at this point.

good point on the canivore(and they aren’t cheap) I was speaking about complete isolation of the drive train.

In this case the author is pretty much there. IMHO the pigeon is the obvious choice for them as it opens up a lot of the CTRE options. There are of course lots of options now so it’s dealers choice…but what I’m recommending to the teams I’m support is to go for the vertical integration and innovate in other areas

posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: Hi so we think we are gonna go with the pigeon but it seems like the ctre code generator is only for Java do you have any recommendations for python( I could be wrong and I just missed the python option) Thanks and have a good one

Yikes I missed the part where you have a Python code base. Frankly I have no idea. One of the reasons I’ve been resistant to Python for our teams is the amount of libraries available in Java.

(And I’m old and I’m refusing to learn python )

posts.name: Angel
posts.cooked:
Yagsl (Yet Another Generic Swerve Library) has plans on releasing support for Python by next season and would be my recommendation.

Through the rumor mill I have heard that CTRE may add additional languages to their Swerve Generator, but thats still a rumor and I havent heard anything about a release date.

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked:
One of several reasons we dont use python as well, I told the students flat out i wouldnt be able to help with code at all if they use it (cant for the life of me wrap my head around it without the extra syntax to tell me where functions start and stop)

That being said, we use a Navx with full Kraken swerve ( SDS though that makes little difference in terms of code) and CTRE cancoders.  While it hasnt exactly been crippling, we have noticed that there is some minor drift that occurs with our drive.  This could be due to the issues posted or it could be part of it being our first year using swerve.  While we could have opted to use a Pigeon, we opted to stick with the NavX since that is what we had on hand and our coders had used that to pilot test our off season Alpha drive base.  For future seasons, im not sure if we will be switching, im leaving that up to the code team’s discretion

tyron256:

cant for the life of me wrap my head around it without the extra syntax to tell me where functions start and stop

OMG PREACH!

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
It really depends on your apporach on coding and you can get very similar result from both two sensor. However my personal experience (as I had tried both sensor in robotpy) would be recommanding Peigon.

As you mentioned you’re using Python, currently the Swerve generated code from phoenix tuner is more for Java thus and don’t have Python support so if you do decide using Python, this feature is nonexistant for you.

Also from my experience with robotpy and Navx, I feel like the library and example is still incomplete and it took me some tweaking to get the example running correctly. On the other hand phoenix API is more complete and better documented.

Also had nobody mentioned the flexability of mounting when it comes to Peigon. IMU do be better mounted as close to the center of rotation of the robot as possible. For Peigon, you could just pull power and CAN wire. Navx is generally mounted on roboRIO and unless you want to hack the wiring (or use USB?? I never tried) and make a 3D printed case for Navx, it pretty much has to stay with your roboRIO. If your roboRIO isn’t at the center of your robot, you than needs to mathematically compensate your Navx’s reading to get a accurate angle reading which could add up drift.

Last but not least, as you had also use CTRE Cancoder and Talon FX motor (Falcon or Kraken), many API would allow you to do PID from remote sensor (even some feature do require a pro license which is behind a paywall), reducing load on roboRIO and less latency .

posts.name: Shai
posts.cooked: We also switched this season and had the exact same experience.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
We have been using the Nav-X2 MXP successfully for years (and the Nav-X 1) before that. This year however, the Nav-X started randomly disconnecting for a half second, and coming back with a different zero offset. We replaced the Nav-X, the Rio, added a usb “backup power source”, updated the firmware… Nothing fixed it. We ended up buying a Pigeon and rewriting our code to suit.

I am not sure who broke the Nav-X code (us, Studica, WPIlib, or NI), but I’m super angry that we had to spend hundreds of dollars to “fix” what wasn’t broken before 2024 .

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
I would personally not recommend a NavX 1, but we have used a NavX2 MXP, and haven’t had any issues. We used a USB-A to mini-USB cable to provide an additional source of power, to prevent the NavX2 from browning out, as well as printing a protective case.

Would have no problem recommending a NavX2.
